p: In addition to monitoring indicators for drought itself [ 47] or drought-related drivers of health impacts [ 241], increased water quality testing and monitoring of drinking water and/or recreational water during droughts can help safeguard health [ 43, 59, 65, 74, 92]. For example, the province of Quebec has begun to adapt by increasing the monitoring of surface water and adopting more stringent standards for water quality surveillance. Water treatment is also an important adaptation to protect against water-borne disease [ 59] and boil-water advisories may be a supportive tool, although they are designed to address fecal and not algal or chemical contamination. During the 2001 drought within the Kanai Blood Indian Reserve in Alberta (Canada), there was an increase in the number of boil water advisories called to protect residents against potential contamination [ 174].
